t: Judges 5
Deborah’s Song
On*p that day Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang:
When*pn the leaders lead in Israel, when*ln the people volunteer, blessed*ln be the Lord.*s
Listen,*ln kings! Pay attention, princes! I*ln will sing to the Lord;*s I*ln will sing praise to the Lord*s God of Israel.
Lord,*sln when you came from Seir, when*ln you marched from the fields of Edom, the*ln earth trembled, the*ln skies poured rain, and*ln the clouds poured water.
The*ln mountains melted before the Lord,*s even*ln Sinai, before the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
In*pn the days of Shamgar son of Anath, in*ln the days of Jael, the*ln main roads were deserted because*ln travelers kept to the side roads.
Villages*ln were deserted, they*ln were deserted in Israel, until*ln I, Deborah, arose, a*ln mother in Israel.
Israel*ln chose new gods, then*ln there was war in the city gates. Not*ln a shield or spear was seen among*ln forty thousand in Israel.
My*ln heart is with the leaders of Israel, with*ln the volunteers of the people. Blessed*ln be the Lord!*s
You*ln who ride on white donkeys, who*ln sit on saddle blankets, and*ln who travel on the road, give praise!

Let*ln them tell the righteous acts of the Lord,*s the*ln righteous deeds of his villagers in Israel, with*ln the voices of the singers at the watering places. Then*ln the Lord’s*s people went down to the city gates.
“Awake!*ln Awake, Deborah! Awake!*ln Awake, sing a song! Arise,*ln Barak, and*ln take your prisoners, son*ln of Abinoam!”
Then*ln the survivors came down to the nobles; the*ln Lord’s*s people came down to me against the warriors.
Those*ln with their roots in Amalek came from Ephraim; Benjamin*ln came with your people after you. The*ln leaders came down from Machir, and*ln those who carry a marshal’s staff came from Zebulun.
The*ln princes of Issachar were with Deborah; Issachar*ln was with Barak; they*ln were under his leadership in the valley. There*ln was great searching of heart among*ln the clans of Reuben.
Why*ln did you sit among the sheep pens listening*ln to the playing of pipes for the flocks? There*ln was great searching of heart among*ln the clans of Reuben.
Gilead*ln remained beyond the Jordan. Dan,*ln why did you linger at the ships? Asher*ln remained at the seashore and*ln stayed in his harbors.
The*ln people of Zebulun defied death, Naphtali*ln also, on the heights of the battlefield.
Kings*pn came and fought. Then*ln the kings of Canaan fought at*ln Taanach by the Waters of Megiddo, but*ln they did not plunder the silver.
The*ln stars fought from the heavens; the*ln stars fought with Sisera from their paths.
The*ln river Kishon swept them away, the*ln ancient river, the river Kishon. March*ln on, my soul, in strength!
The*ln horses’ hooves then hammered — the*ln galloping, galloping of his stallions.
“Curse*ln Meroz,” says the angel of the Lord,*s “Bitterly*ln curse her inhabitants, for*ln they did not come to help the Lord,*s to*ln help the Lord*s with the warriors.”
Most*pn blessed of women is Jael, the*ln wife of Heber the Kenite; she*ln is most blessed among tent-dwelling women.
He*ln asked for water; she gave him milk. She*ln brought him cream in a majestic bowl.
She*ln reached for a tent peg, her*ln right hand, for a workman’s hammer. Then*ln she hammered Sisera — she*ln crushed his head; she*ln shattered and pierced his temple.
He*ln collapsed, he fell, he lay down between her feet; he*ln collapsed, he fell between her feet; where*ln he collapsed, there he fell - dead.
Sisera’s*pn mother looked through the window; she*ln peered through the lattice, crying out: “Why*ln is his chariot so long in coming? Why*ln don’t I hear the hoofbeats of his horses?”
Her*ln wisest princesses answer her; she*ln even answers herself:
“Are*ln they not finding and dividing the spoil — a*ln girl or two for each warrior, the*ln spoil of colored garments for Sisera, the*ln spoil of an embroidered garment or two for my neck?”
Lord,*spn may all your enemies perish as Sisera did. But*ln may those who love him be*ln like the rising of the sun in its strength. And*p the land had peace for forty years.
